mCOUGx-y6.memHandModelNotes: Meegan & Maehr (2002) created a habitat model to assess conservation strategies, particularly dispersal into unoccupied but potential habitat, in which they buffered forest 90m-excluding mangrove-then buffered roads 500m and urban 90m, using these as a mask.  They used a minimum patch size of 500ha and smaller patches within 2km.  Kerkhoff et al. (2000) assessed panther habitat in relation to forest cover.  They used a lower limit of 3% canopy cover within 900km^2 to define forested habitat.  Per Kacy's direction to the recent publication by Beier et al. (2003), I eliminated the minimum patch size of 500ha from the model: "Although available data clearly indicate the importance of forests and forest cover to panthers, we find no basis for the ideas that panthers are reluctant to move greater than 90 m from forest cover, that panthers avoid forest patches smaller than 500 ha, or that BCNP and ENP do not provide useful habitat for panthers." (from recommendations in Beier et al. 2003).  I don't think they will venture too far out into pasture/ag or open prairie in south FL, so I decided to include a buffer of 250m on the primary MUs (i.e. 0 ha meaning all cells) into auxiliary MUs to try and eliminate large patches of ag/pasture/open veg.  This distance is purely subjective but almost 3 times the recommended distance of Maehr of which Beier has such a problem and also includes cover types other than forest.

references: Katnik, D. D. 2002. Predation and habitat ecology of mountain lions (Puma concolor) in the southern Selkirk Mountains. Dissertation, Washington State University, Pullman, Washington, USA.

Fleming, Marty. Distribution, Abundance, and Demography of White-tailed Deer in the Everglades.Dennis B. Jordan. 1994. Proceedings of The Florida Panther Conference; Ft. Myers, Florida.  U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service; pg. 247-274.

Caso, A., Lopez-Gonzalez, C., Payan, E., Eizirik, E., de Oliveira, T., Leite-Pitman, R., Kelly, M., Valderrama, C. & Lucherini, M. 2008. Puma concolor. In: IUCN 2012. IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2012.1. <www.iucnredlist.org>. Downloaded on 12 July 2012.

Young, S. P. and E. A. Goldman. 1946. The Puma, mysterious American cat. Part I (by Young). History, life habits, economic status, and control. Part II (by Goldman). Classification of the races of the puma. American Wildlife Institute (also Dover Publ., I

Comiskey, E. J., O. L. Bass, Jr., L. J. Gross, R. T. McBride, and R. Salinas. 2002. Panthers and forests in South Florida: an ecological perspective. Conservation Ecology 6(1): 18. [online] URL: http://www.consecol.org/vol6/iss1/art18/
Kerkhoff, A.J., B.T. Milne, and D.S. Maehr. 2000, Toward a panther-centered view of the forests of south Florida: Conservation Ecology. 4 (1):1 Available online at www.consecol.org.vol4/iss1/art1.
Schmidly, D. J. 2004. The mammals of Texas. Revised ed. University of Texas Press, Austin.
Currier, M.J.P.. 1983. Felis concolor. American Society of Mammalogists, Mammalian Species No. 200: 1-7.

Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission. 2013. Florida panther (Puma concolor coryi) telemetry locations, February 1981 - June 2013. Online linkage http://www.floridapanthernet.org/. Data accessed March 2014.

Tesky, Julie L. 1995. Puma concolor. In: Fire Effects Information System, [Online]. U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station, Fire Sciences Laboratory (Producer). Available: http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/ [Accessed: 2012, July 12].
Laing, S. P. 1988. Cougar habitat selection and spatial use patterns in southern Utah. Thesis, Utah State University, Logan, Utah.
Maehr, D. S. 1992. Florida Panther Distribution and Conservation Strategy. Gainesville, FL: Florida Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission.
Hall, E. R. 1981. The Mammals of North America. Second edition. 2 Volumes. John Wiley and Sons, New York, New York. 1181 p.

Beier, P., M.R. Vaughan, M.J. Conroy, and H. Quigley. 2003, An analysis of scientific literature related to the Florida panther: Submitted as final report for Project NG01-105, Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission, Tallahassee, FL. 203 pp.
Trani, M. K., W. M. Ford, and B. R. Chapman (eds.) 2007. The Land Manager's Guide to Mammals of the South. The Nature Conservancy, Southeastern Region, Durham, NC, USA. 546 pp.

Maehr, D. S.; E. D. Land; J. C. Roof, and J. W. McCowan. Day beds, natal dens, and activity of Florida panthers. Proceedings of the Annual Conference of Southeastern Fish and Wildlife Agencies. 44:310-318.

Maehr, D.S. 2004. Review of "An analysis of scientific publications related to the Florida panther." Memorandum submitted to Florida Panther Scientific Review Team and Florida Panther Recovery Team. [online] URL: http://www.eswr.com/104/srtmaehrresponse.pdf
Schrupp, D.L., and A. Cade 1989 Colorado Wildlife Species Database - User's Guide. Colorado Division of Wildlife. DOW-HR-01-89. Denver, CO.

habitat_description:
Puma concolor utilizes a broad range of habitats.

Western cougars inhabit riparian vegetation (Logan and Irwin, 1985; Koehler and Hornocker, 1991; Dickson and Beier, 2002; Nicholson, 2009), chaparral (Dickson and Beier, 2002; Nicholson, 2009), montane and subalpine mixed conifer forest (Logan and Irwin, 1985; Laing, 1988; Koehler and Hornocker, 1991; McRae, 2004; Katnik, 2002; Rieth, 2010), spruce-fir forest (Laing, 1988; McRae, 2004), pinyon-juniper woodlands (Laing, 1988; McRae, 2004; Stoner et al., 2008; Nicholson, 2009), coastal forest (McRae, 2004), Douglas-fir forest (Seidensticker et al., 1973; Logan and Irwin, 1985; Koehler and Hornocker, 1991; McRae, 2004), curlleaf mountain mahogany shrubland (Logan and Irwin, 1985), ponderosa pine woodland and forest (Seidensticker et al., 1973; Laing, 1988; McRae, 2004), ponderosa pine-oak woodlands (Laing, 1988), mountain sagebrush (Logan and Irwin, 1985; McRae, 2004), and deciduous and conifer woodlands (McRae, 2004; Stoner et al., 2008; Nicholson, 2009; Rieth, 2010). 

Given identical vegetative composition between sites, the species prefers sites with a denser understory and on steeper slopes (Laing, 1988). Dense shrub or sapling cover, rugged rock outcrops, boulder piles, and overhanging cliffs provide the cover necessary for mountain lions to stalk prey (Hornocker, 1970; Seidensticker et al., 1973; Beier et al., 1995). Logan and Irwin (1985) document occasional, successful kills in open habitat, but never farther than 250 from dense, tall vegetation or canyons.

Aside from slight incursions into open habitats while hunting (Logan and Irwin, 1985) and occasional rapid dispersal treks (Stoner et al., 2008), these western individuals avoid open grassland/meadows (Seidensticker et al., 1973; Laing, 1988; Dickson and Beier, 2002; Nicholson, 2009), low-growing scrub/shrub (Laing, 1988; Harveson, 1997; Stoner et al., 2008; Nicholson, 2009), barren land (Harveson, 1997; McRae, 2004), slickrock sandstone canyons (Laing, 1988), sagebrush bottomlands (Laing, 1988), cropland (Laing, 1988; McRae, 2004; Nicholson, 2009), pasture (Laing, 1988), urban or developed areas (Dickson and Beier, 2002; Nicholson, 2009), and gentle slopes (Logan and Irwin, 1985).

In south Florida, P. concolor coryi inhabits hammock forests (Maehr and Cox, 1995; Belden et al., 1988; Dees et al., 2001), mixed swamp forests (Belden et al., 1988; Cox et al., 2006; Benson, 2008), upland hardwoods (Benson, 2008), pine scrub (Benson, 2008), conifer and hardwood forests (Dees et al., 2001; Cox et al., 2006; Land et al., 2008), cypress swamps (Maehr and Cox, 1995; Dees et al., 2001); forested wetlands (Land et al., 2008).

Maehr and Cox (1995) found that 96% of P. concolor observations were within 90 m of “preferred” cover types, which they defined as hardwood hammocks, hardwood swamps, and cypress swamps. Comsikey et al. (2002) and Shrader-Frechette (2004) argue that mosaics including open marsh and prairie in proximity to forest and shrublands are ideal habitat (see also: Belden et al., 1988).

The Florida subspecies (coryi) generally avoids prairies (Maehr and Cox, 1995; Belden et al., 1988), marshes (Belden et al., 1988; Dees et al., 2001; Cox et al., 2006; Benson et al., 2008), agricultural land (Maehr and Cox, 1995; Dees et al., 2001; Cox et al., 2006; Land et al., 2008), and developed areas (Dees et al., 2001; Cox et al., 2006).

North American P. concolor have been reported at elevations from sea level up to 4,000 m (Currier, 1983).
